title: Atom plots
text: atom plot corresponds simple plot can combined atom plots form final molecule plot, often complex.

title: Atom plots
text: tlf function initializePlot creates empty plot whose properties defined PlotConfiguration object. function initializePlot called every tlf plot function plotObject provided input returns regular ggplot object includes additional field named plotConfiguration defining properties PlotConfiguration object. detailed presentation PlotConfiguration objects available vignette plot-configuration. examples use initializePlot shown . Initialize empty plot current theme (plotConfiguration input)  Initialize empty plot labels defined plotConfiguration input  metaData provides dimension unit, labels dimension [unit] default. data provided, labels include column name default xlabel ylabel used, replace default
code: initializePlot() # Create a PlotConfiguration object to specify plot properties (here labels) myConfiguration <- PlotConfiguration$new(   title = "My empty plot",   xlabel = "My X axis",   ylabel = "My Y axis" ) # Use the obect to define the plot properties initializePlot(plotConfiguration = myConfiguration) # data.frame for example knitr::kable(head(cosData)) # Define which is x and y variables using dataMapping cosMapping <- XYGDataMapping$new(x = "time", y = "cos")  # Define the metaData cosMetaData <- list(   time = list(     dimension = "Time",     unit = "min"   ),   cos = list(     dimension = "Cosinus",     unit = ""   ) ) cosMetaData #> $time #> $time$dimension #> [1] "Time" #>  #> $time$unit #> [1] "min" #>  #>  #> $cos #> $cos$dimension #> [1] "Cosinus" #>  #> $cos$unit #> [1] "" # Define default Configuration with metaData metaDataConfiguration <- PlotConfiguration$new(   title = "Cosinus plot",   data = cosData,   metaData = cosMetaData,   dataMapping = cosMapping )  initializePlot(plotConfiguration = metaDataConfiguration) # Define default Configuration with metaData dataConfiguration <- PlotConfiguration$new(   title = "Cosinus plot",   data = cosData,   dataMapping = cosMapping )  initializePlot(plotConfiguration = dataConfiguration) # Define default Configuration with metaData overwriteConfiguration <- PlotConfiguration$new(   title = "Cosinus plot",   ylabel = "new y label",   data = cosData,   metaData = cosMetaData,   dataMapping = cosMapping )  initializePlot(plotConfiguration = overwriteConfiguration)

title: Atom plots
text: function addScatter returns scatter plot. Likewise tlf plot functions, input argument data metaData can used defined plot.  argument plotConfiguration also works way initializePlot:  function addScatter also supports x y inputs instead data dataMapping. case, function internally create data.frame x y column names along data mapping.  also possible prove plotConfiguration define properties especially labels plot created process.  Additionally, optional arguments can used overwrite default specific properties plotConfiguration. color: color scatter points. Note multiple colors can provided dataMapping defines multiple groups. shape: shape scatter points. Note multiple shapes can provided dataMapping defines multiple groups. size: size scatter points. Note multiple shapes can provided dataMapping defines multiple groups. linetype: linetype lines connecting scatter points. Note multiple linetypes can provided dataMapping defines multiple groups. caption: Name legend caption scatter points. Note multiple captions can provided dataMapping defines multiple groups.  input argument plotObject used, scatter layer added top input plot use plotConfiguration plotObject.
code: addScatter(   data = cosData,   metaData = cosMetaData,   dataMapping = cosMapping ) addScatter(   data = cosData,   metaData = cosMetaData,   dataMapping = cosMapping,   plotConfiguration = overwriteConfiguration ) addScatter(   x = cosData$time,   y = cosData$cos ) addScatter(   x = cosData$time,   y = cosData$cos,   plotConfiguration = overwriteConfiguration ) addScatter(   x = cosData$time,   y = cosData$cos,   color = "firebrick",   shape = Shapes$cardsHeart,   size = 3,   caption = "heart" ) scatterPlot <- addScatter(   x = cosData$time,   y = cosData$cos,   color = "firebrick",   shape = Shapes$cardsHeart,   size = 3,   caption = "heart",   plotConfiguration = overwriteConfiguration )  scatterPlot addScatter(   x = cosData$time,   y = cosData$cos + 2,   color = "black",   shape = Shapes$cardsSpade,   size = 3,   caption = "spade",   plotObject = scatterPlot )

title: Atom plots
text: function addLine returns line plot. arguments addScatter can used addLine, default properties different.   Since line plots can inlcude horizontal vertical lines, addLine possibility using x y input x/y-intercepts. functions addScatter addLine can also combined:
code: addLine(   x = cosData$time,   y = cosData$cos ) addLine(   x = cosData$time,   y = cosData$cos,   color = "firebrick",   linetype = Linetypes$longdash,   size = 1,   caption = "line with\nlong dashes" ) addLine(   y = c(1, 2, 3),   caption = "horizontal lines" ) addLine(   x = c(1, 2, 3),   caption = "vertical lines" ) scatterPlot <- addScatter(   x = cosData$time,   y = cosData$cos,   color = "firebrick",   shape = Shapes$cardsHeart,   size = 3,   caption = "heart",   plotConfiguration = overwriteConfiguration )  scatterPlot  addLine(   y = 0.5,   color = "dodgerblue",   linetype = Linetypes$solid,   size = 0.5,   caption = "threshold",   plotObject = scatterPlot )

title: Atom plots
text: function addRibbon returns ribbon plot. Ribbons require ymin ymax inputs. Consequently, different dataMapping type RangeDataMapping necessary compared addLine addScatter require XYGDataMapping.  function addRibbon also supports x, ymin ymax inputs instead data dataMapping.  ribbons, optional inputs include fill alpha defining color transparency ribbon, respectively.  Note transparency input, alpha, value 0 1. closer 0, transparent fill color . closer 1, visible fill color .
code: sinCosMapping <- RangeDataMapping$new(   x = "time",   ymin = "sin",   ymax = "cos" )  addRibbon(   data = cosData,   metaData = cosMetaData,   dataMapping = sinCosMapping ) addRibbon(   x = cosData$time,   ymin = cosData$sin,   ymax = cosData$cos ) addRibbon(   x = cosData$time,   ymin = cosData$sin,   ymax = cosData$cos,   fill = "firebrick",   alpha = 0.5,   caption = "ribbon plot" )

title: Atom plots
text: function addErrorbar returns error bar plot. ribbons, error bars require ymin ymax inputs.  Among optional inputs, addErrorbar proposes includeCap logical defines caps included extremities error bars.  Note optional inputs addErrorbar define aesthetic bars (link bars). Thus, two layers necessary creating plot inlcuded data error bars.
code: addErrorbar(   x = cosData$time,   ymin = cosData$sin,   ymax = cosData$cos ) addErrorbar(   x = cosData$time,   ymin = cosData$sin,   ymax = cosData$cos,   color = "firebrick",   linetype = Linetypes$solid,   includeCap = TRUE,   size = 0.5,   caption = "error bar plot" ) errorPlot <- addErrorbar(   x = cosData$time,   ymin = cosData$cos - 0.1,   ymax = cosData$cos + 0.2,   caption = "error",   color = "black",   size = 0.5,   plotConfiguration = overwriteConfiguration )  errorPlot addScatter(   x = cosData$time,   y = cosData$cos,   color = "firebrick",   shape = Shapes$cardsHeart,   size = 3,   caption = "heart",   plotObject = errorPlot )

title: Box-whisker plots
text: following vignette aims documenting illustrating workflows producing box--whisker plots using tlf-Library. vignette focuses boxplot examples. Detailed documentation typical tlf workflow, use AgregationSummary, DataMapping, PlotConfiguration Theme can found vignette("tlf-workflow").

title: Box-whisker plots
text: function plotting box-whiskers : plotBoxWhisker. Basic documentation function can found using: ?plotBoxWhisker. typical usage function : plotBoxWhisker(data, metaData = NULL, dataMapping = NULL, plotConfiguration = NULL). output function ggplot object.

title: Box-whisker plots
text: dataMapping plotBoxWhisker requires BoxWhiskerDataMapping class. class can simply initialized BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(), needing y variable name input . boxplots multiple boxes, x variable name /fill groupMapping can used. x variable expected factor levels. Beside common input, possible overwrite aggregation functions plot edges box, whiskers outlying data. box edges lower, middle, upper correspond first quartile, median, third quartile (25th, 50th, 75th percentiles), respectively. whiskers, ymin ymax use 5th 95th percentiles. outliers, points lower 25th percentile - 1.5 x IQR points higher 75th percentile + 1.5 x IQR (IQR inter-quartile range) flagged plotted. order help boxplot aggregation functions, bank predefined function names already available tlfStatFunctions (enum). Consequently, tree available predefined function names appear writing tlfStatFunctions$: ‘mean’, ‘sd’, ‘min’, ‘max’, ‘mean-sd’, ‘mean+sd’, ‘mean-1.96sd’, ‘mean+1.96sd’, ‘Percentile0%’, ‘Percentile1%’, ‘Percentile2.5%’, ‘Percentile5%’, ‘Percentile10%’, ‘Percentile15%’, ‘Percentile20%’, ‘Percentile25%’, ‘Percentile50%’, ‘Percentile75%’, ‘Percentile80%’, ‘Percentile85%’, ‘Percentile90%’, ‘Percentile95%’, ‘Percentile97.5%’, ‘Percentile99%’, ‘Percentile100%’, ‘median-IQR’, ‘median+IQR’, ‘median-1.5IQR’, ‘median+1.5IQR’, ‘Percentile25%-1.5IQR’, ‘Percentile75%+1.5IQR’,

title: Box-whisker plots
text: illustrate workflow produce boxplots, let’s use pkRatioDataExample.RData example data extdata folder. includes dataset pkRatioData: also need prepare corresponding metaData pkRatioMetaData:
code: # Load example pkRatioData <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata", "test-data.csv", package = "tlf"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # pkRatioData knitr::kable(utils::head(pkRatioData), digits = 2) # Load example pkRatioMetaData <- list(   Age = list(     dimension = "Age",     unit = "yrs"   ),   Obs = list(     dimension = "Clearance",     unit = "dL/h/kg"   ),   Pred = list(     dimension = "Clearance",     unit = "dL/h/kg"   ),   Ratio = list(     dimension = "Ratio",     unit = ""   ) ) knitr::kable(data.frame(   Variable = c("Age", "Obs", "Pred", "Ratio"),   Dimension = c("Age", "Clearance", "Clearance", "Ratio"),   Unit = c("yrs", "dL/h/kg", "dL/h/kg", "") ))

title: Box-whisker plots
text: minimal example, basic y variable name indicated. , "Age" chosen boxplot.
code: minMap <- BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(y = "Age")  minBoxplot <- plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = minMap ) minBoxplot

title: Box-whisker plots
text: plot, x /fill can provided. x provided, plot use x variable aggregation boxplots displayed according x. providing fill, plot use fill groupMapping aggregation boxplots displayed around x comparing color filling. Consequently, fill variable useful performing double comparison. example , "Country" "Sex" can used comparison "Age". Boxplot mapping Country x Note sample given country sometimes individual one sexes. Boxplot mapping Sex x Boxplot mapping Country fill Boxplot mapping Sex fill Boxplot mapping Country x Sex fill Boxplot mapping Sex x Country fill
code: xPopMap <- BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(   x = "Country",   y = "Age" )  xSexMap <- BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(   x = "Sex",   y = "Age" )  fillPopMap <- BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(   y = "Age",   fill = "Country" )  fillSexMap <- BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(   y = "Age",   fill = "Sex" ) xPopFillSexMap <- BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(   x = "Country",   y = "Age",   fill = "Sex" )  xSexFillPopMap <- BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(   x = "Sex",   y = "Age",   fill = "Country" ) plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = xPopMap ) plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = xSexMap ) plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = fillPopMap ) plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = fillSexMap ) plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = xPopFillSexMap ) plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = xSexFillPopMap )

title: Box-whisker plots
text: cases, displaying 5th 95th percentiles necessary. instance, normal distribution assumed, mean +/- 1.96 standard deviation preferred. cases, easy overwrite default functions specifying either using home made function directly using predefined functions suggested section 2.2. following examples, boxplot use mean middle line mean +/- 1.96 standard deviation whiskers: Boxplot mapping Country x, Sex fill assuming normal distribution example, boxplot use also mean +/- standard deviation box edges Boxplot mapping Country x, Sex fill assuming normal distribution Important: override defaults way, please make sure specify plot annotations basically redefining boxplot reader might aware misinterpret plot.
code: normMap <- BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(   x = "Country",   y = "Age",   fill = "Sex",   ymin = tlfStatFunctions$`mean-1.96sd`,   middle = tlfStatFunctions$mean,   ymax = tlfStatFunctions$`mean+1.96sd` )  normBoxplot <- plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = normMap ) normBoxplot normMap2 <- BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(   x = "Country",   y = "Age",   fill = "Sex",   ymin = tlfStatFunctions$`mean-1.96sd`,   lower = tlfStatFunctions$`mean-sd`,   middle = tlfStatFunctions$mean,   upper = tlfStatFunctions$`mean+sd`,   ymax = tlfStatFunctions$`mean+1.96sd` )  normBoxplot2 <- plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = normMap2 ) normBoxplot2

title: Box-whisker plots
text: Default outliers flagged outside range 25th percentiles - 1.5 x IQR 75th percentiles + 1.5 x IQR, suggested McGill implemented current boxplot functions ggplot (geom_boxplot). However, default can also overridden. following example, outliers flagged values 10th-90th percentiles, whiskers go percentiles: Boxplot mapping Country x, Sex fill assuming normal distribution
code: outlierMap <- BoxWhiskerDataMapping$new(   x = "Country",   y = "Age",   fill = "Sex",   ymin = tlfStatFunctions$`Percentile10%`,   ymax = tlfStatFunctions$`Percentile90%`,   minOutlierLimit = tlfStatFunctions$`Percentile10%`,   maxOutlierLimit = tlfStatFunctions$`Percentile90%` )  outlierBoxplot <- plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = outlierMap ) outlierBoxplot

title: Box-whisker plots
text: define properties boxes points box whisker plots, BoxWhiskerPlotConfiguration object can defined overwrite default properties. ribbons points fields define boxes outliers handled. Using previous example country defined x gender color. Boxplot updated plot configuration
code: # Define a PlotConfiguration object using smart mapping boxplotConfiguration <- BoxWhiskerPlotConfiguration$new(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = xPopFillSexMap )  # Change the properties of the box colors boxplotConfiguration$ribbons$fill <- c("pink", "dodgerblue") boxplotConfiguration$ribbons$color <- "orange"  # Change the properties of the points (outliers) boxplotConfiguration$points$size <- 2 boxplotConfiguration$points$shape <- Shapes$diamond  plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = pkRatioMetaData,   dataMapping = xPopFillSexMap,   plotConfiguration = boxplotConfiguration )

title: Box-whisker plots
text: Since boxplot data mapping performs aggregation data, possible get directly resulting aggregated statistic table using getBoxWhiskerLimits(). Similarly, can used flag values certain range using getOutliers(). instance, using example section 3.5, one can get following results
code: boxplotSummary <- outlierMap$getBoxWhiskerLimits(pkRatioData)  knitr::kable(boxplotSummary, digits = 2) outliers <- outlierMap$getOutliers(pkRatioData) outliers <- outliers[, c("Age", "minOutlierLimit", "maxOutlierLimit", "minOutliers", "maxOutliers")]  knitr::kable(utils::head(outliers), digits = 2)

title: Histogram plots
text: following vignette aims documenting illustrating workflows producing histograms using function plotHistogram tlf package.

title: Histogram plots
text: data showed sequel available following path: system.file("extdata", "test-data.csv", package = "tlf"). code , data loaded assigned histData.
code: # Load example histData <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata", "test-data.csv", package = "tlf"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # histData knitr::kable(utils::head(histData), digits = 2)

title: Histogram plots
text: Besides, usual tlf input arguments commonly used plot functions (data, metaData, dataMapping, plotConfiguration plotObject), function plotHistogram also includes following optional input arguments: x: Numeric values used histogram instead data dataMapping. bins: Number bins binwidth: Width bin, overwrting number bins. stack: Logical defining histogram bars stacked distribution: Name distribution fit data. Currently, normal log-normal distributions available.

title: Histogram plots
text: time, optional input x convenient assess distribution data.
code: # Use directly x for quick histogram plotHistogram(x = histData$Ratio) # Use directly x and bins for quick histogram with a defined number of bins plotHistogram(x = histData$Ratio, bins = 7)

title: Histogram plots
text: Workflows tlf usually includes definition data, metData dataMapping.  cases, optional arguments previously presented can included dataMapping.  defined plotHistogram input arguments, overwrite dataMapping.
code: # Create HistogramDataMapping object histoMapping <- HistogramDataMapping$new(   x = "Ratio",   fill = "Sex"   )  plotHistogram(   data = histData,   dataMapping = histoMapping   ) # Create HistogramDataMapping object histoMapping <- HistogramDataMapping$new(   x = "Ratio",   fill = "Sex",   stack = TRUE   )  plotHistogram(   data = histData,   dataMapping = histoMapping   ) # Create HistogramDataMapping object histoMapping <- HistogramDataMapping$new(   x = "Ratio",   fill = "Sex",   bins = 3   )  # bin defined in both, plotHistogram has priority and overwrites dataMapping internally plotHistogram(   data = histData,   dataMapping = histoMapping,   bins = 6   )

title: Histogram plots
text: 3 ways defining data binned. priority method defined according specificity. Method 1, simplest used default, defines number bins. can overwritten method 3, defines width bin. Method 2 specific defines bin edges, consequently overwritten method 3. *1. Define number bins input argument bins (using single value)  *2. Define edges bins input argument bins (using array values)  *3. Define width bins input argument binwidth (using single value).
code: # Create HistogramDataMapping object histoMapping <- HistogramDataMapping$new(   x = "Ratio",   fill = "Sex"   )  # Define the number of bins in final plot plotHistogram(   data = histData,   dataMapping = histoMapping,   bins = 6   ) # Create HistogramDataMapping object histoMapping <- HistogramDataMapping$new(   x = "Ratio",   fill = "Sex"   )  # Define the edges of bins in final plot plotHistogram(   data = histData,   dataMapping = histoMapping,   bins = seq(0,6,0.2)   ) # Create HistogramDataMapping object histoMapping <- HistogramDataMapping$new(   x = "Ratio",   fill = "Sex"   )  # Define the width of bins in final plot plotHistogram(   data = histData,   dataMapping = histoMapping,   binwidth = 0.4   )

title: Histogram plots
text: optional input distribution aims providing possibility fitting data distribution. Currently, two distributions can fitted function plotHistogram: Fit normal distribution draw distribution mean vertical line using "normal" Fit log-normal distribution draw distribution mode vertical line using "logNormal"   compare multiple distributions, can defined dataMapping:  option stack, also possible get distribution sum splitting content bars.  HistogramPlotConfiguration objects can used tune final plot aesthetics.
code: # Plot normal distribution plotHistogram(   x = histData$Ratio,   distribution = "normal"   ) # Plot normal distribution plotHistogram(   x = histData$Ratio,   distribution = "logNormal"   ) # Create HistogramDataMapping object split by gender histoMapping <- HistogramDataMapping$new(   x = "Ratio",   fill = "Sex"   )  # Plot normal distribution for each gender plotHistogram(   data = histData,   dataMapping = histoMapping,   distribution = "normal"   ) # Create HistogramDataMapping object split by gender histoMapping <- HistogramDataMapping$new(   x = "Ratio",   fill = "Sex"   )  # Plot normal distribution of sum but bars are split by gender plotHistogram(   data = histData,   dataMapping = histoMapping,   distribution = "normal",   stack = TRUE   ) histoConfiguration <- HistogramPlotConfiguration$new(   xlabel = "Ratios",   ylabel = "Occurences" ) histoConfiguration$ribbons$fill <- "grey80" histoConfiguration$lines$color <- "firebrick"  # Plot normal distribution of sum but bars are split by gender plotHistogram(   x = histData$Ratio,   plotConfiguration = histoConfiguration,   distribution = "normal"   )

title: PK Ratio plots
text: following vignette aims documenting illustrating workflows producing PK ratio plots using tlf-Library. vignette focuses PK ratio plots examples. Detailed documentation typical tlf workflow, use AgregationSummary, DataMapping, PlotConfiguration, Theme can found vignette("tlf-workflow").

title: PK Ratio plots
text: data showed sequel available following path: system.file("extdata", "test-data.csv", package = "tlf"). code , data loaded assigned pkRatioData. list information pkRatioData can provided metaData.
code: # Load example pkRatioData <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata", "test-data.csv", package = "tlf"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # pkRatioData knitr::kable(utils::head(pkRatioData), digits = 2) knitr::kable(data.frame(   Variable = c("Age", "Obs", "Pred", "Ratio"),   Dimension = c("Age", "Clearance", "Clearance", "Ratio"),   Unit = c("yrs", "dL/h/kg", "dL/h/kg", "") ))

title: PK Ratio plots
text: function plotting PK ratios : plotPKRatio(). Basic documentation function can found using: ?plotPKRatio. typical usage function : plotPKRatio(data, metaData = NULL, dataMapping = NULL, plotConfiguration = NULL). output function ggplot object. can seen usage data necessary input. Default set ups used metaData, dataMapping plotConfiguration within call plotPKRatio. instance, dataMapping provided, smart mapping check data contains "x" "y" columns. data two columns named "x" "y", assume first one plot x-axis second y-axis. , PKRatioPlotConfiguration initialized provided, defining standard configuration PK Ratio Plot title, current date subtitle using predefined fonts defined current theme.

title: PK Ratio plots
text: minimal example can work using directly function plotPKRatio(data = pkRatioData[, c("Age", "Ratio")]).

title: PK Ratio plots
text: PK ratio, dataMapping class PKRatioDataMapping includes 4 fields: x, y, groupMapping lines. x y define variables data plotted X- Y-axes, groupMapping class mapping aesthtic property split variables, lines defines horizontal lines performed PK ratio plots.

title: PK Ratio plots
text: variables can used cluster data. end, PKRatioDataMapping objects include GroupMapping objects can define cluster based variable data.frame. illustrated , time, direct input color shape faster define objects. Consequently, following examples identical: , example, plotPKRatio can use groupMapping split data “Gender” associate different colors “Gender”:  Multiple groupMappings can performed PK ratio: data can regrouped color, shape /size. next example uses 2 groups groupMapping: One group splits “Gender” color, splits shape “Amount” “Compound”.  last examples uses another feature available groupMapping class. class can initilized using data.frame last column data.frame used split data. following example, data.frame following: dataMapping introduced split color shape using data frame.
code: # Two-step process colorMapping <- GroupMapping$new(color = "Sex") dataMappingA <- PKRatioDataMapping$new(   x = "Age",   y = "Ratio",   groupMapping = colorMapping )  print(dataMappingA$groupMapping$color$label) #> [1] "Sex"  # One-step process dataMappingB <- PKRatioDataMapping$new(   x = "Age",   y = "Ratio",   color = "Sex" )  print(dataMappingB$groupMapping$color$label) #> [1] "Sex" plotPKRatio(   data = pkRatioData,   dataMapping = dataMappingB ) dataMapping2groups <- PKRatioDataMapping$new(   x = "Age",   y = "Ratio",   color = "Sex",   shape = c("Country", "AgeBin") ) plotPKRatio(   data = pkRatioData,   dataMapping = dataMapping2groups ) dataMappingDF <- PKRatioDataMapping$new(   x = "Age",   y = "Ratio",   color = groupDataFrame,   shape = groupDataFrame ) plotPKRatio(   data = pkRatioData[!(pkRatioData$Country %in% "France"), ],   dataMapping = dataMappingDF )

title: PK Ratio plots
text: PK ratio examples, usually horizontal lines added allowing flag values [0.67-1.5] well [0.5-2.0] ranges. value mapping horizontal lines predefined list: “pkRatioLine1” 1, “pkRatioLine2” c(0.67, 1.5) “pkRatioLine3” c(0.5, 2). Consequently, default PKRatioDataMapping, : Overwriting value possible updating value either initializing mapping afterwards. instance:
code: linesMapping <- PKRatioDataMapping$new() linesMapping$lines #> $pkRatio1 #> [1] 1 #>  #> $pkRatio2 #> [1] 1.5000000 0.6666667 #>  #> $pkRatio3 #> [1] 2.0 0.5 linesMapping <- PKRatioDataMapping$new(   lines = list(pkRatio1 = 1, pkRatio2 = c(0.2, 5)),   x = "Age",   y = "Ratio",   color = "Sex" ) plotPKRatio(   data = pkRatioData,   dataMapping = linesMapping )

title: PK Ratio plots
text: qualification PK Ratios can performed using getPKRatioMeasure. function return data.frame PK ratios within specific ranges. default, ranges within 1.5 2 folds. However, can updated using option ratioLimits = running function. Qualification PK Ratios
code: # Test of getPKRatioMeasure PKRatioMeasure <- getPKRatioMeasure(data = pkRatioData[, c("Age", "Ratio")])  knitr::kable(   x = PKRatioMeasure,   caption = "Qualification of PK Ratios" )

title: PK Ratio plots
text: configure plot properties, PKRatioPlotConfiguration objects can used. combine multiple features set plot properties. PK ratio plot consists lines points. illustrated vignette related PlotConfiguration objects Theme, can tune aesthetic maps selections (see vignette("plot-configuration") vignette("theme-maker")). Colors, shapes size PK ratio scatter points can tuned plotConfiguration points field. Likewise, colors, linetype size PK ratio lines can tuned plotConfiguration lines field.

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: PlotConfiguration objects R6 class objects define plot properties. create object, method new() required. Multiple arguments can passed method order directly define properties. properties default values can handled managed using concept themes. example illustrates, following properties accounted PlotConfiguration class. properties managed different R6 class object detailed next sections: labels background xAxis/yAxis legend save ggplot object initialized using tlf method initializePlot, plotConfiguration field implanted plot object. plotConfiguration field class subclass PlotConfiguration aims simplifying clarifying plot properties mentioned . PlotConfiguration objects can also directly passed method initializePlot shown : left: emptyPlot; right: myEmptyPlot
code: myConfiguration <- PlotConfiguration$new() # myConfiguration$print()  myConfiguration <- PlotConfiguration$new(   title = "my title",   watermark = "my watermark" ) # myConfiguration$print() emptyPlot <- initializePlot()  myEmptyPlot <- initializePlot(myConfiguration)

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: field labels PlotConfiguration object LabelConfiguration object. defines label properties following plot captions: title subtitle xlabel ylabel field Label object associate text font properties: initializing LabelConfiguration PlotConfiguration object, Label /character objects can passed . Character objects converted Label objects internally using current theme.
code: title <- Label$new(   text = "This is a title text",   font = Font$new(     color = "red",     size = 12   ) ) myRedPlotLabel <- LabelConfiguration$new(title = Label$new(   text = "my title",   color = "red" ))

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: effect label configuration plots straightforward: left: pLab1; right: pLab2
code: plotConfigurationLabel1 <- PlotConfiguration$new(   title = "Title",   subtitle = "Subtitle",   xlabel = "x label",   ylabel = "y label" )  pLab1 <- initializePlot(plotConfigurationLabel1)  plotConfigurationLabel2 <- PlotConfiguration$new(   title = Label$new(text = "Title", size = 12, color = "deepskyblue4"),   subtitle = Label$new(text = "Subtitle", size = 11, color = "steelblue"),   xlabel = Label$new(text = "x label", size = 10, color = "dodgerblue2"),   ylabel = Label$new(text = "y label", size = 10, color = "dodgerblue2") )  pLab2 <- initializePlot(plotConfigurationLabel2)

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: creating plot, possible change label configuration using tlf method setPlotLabels. method requires plot object label property update. Similar construction Label configuration, Label /character objects can passed . Using previous example, pLab2,
code: setPlotLabels(pLab2, title = "new title") setPlotLabels(pLab2, title = Label$new(text = "new title", color = "red"))

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: Smart plot labels available initializing PlotConfiguration objects. principle provide advance data used within plot. consequence, three optional arguments can passed PlotConfiguration initialization: data, metaData dataMapping. label specifically defined, smart configuration fetch x y labels within data metaData names based dataMapping. dataMapping also uses smart functions check input data frame - specifically initialized - use variables named “x” “y” x y. four examples illustrate smart configurations: pSmart1 pSmart2 turn , pSmart3 use information metaData write x y labels. pSmart4 overwrite y label title based input. left: pSmart1; right: pSmart2 left: pSmart3; right: pSmart4 Since tlf plots internally using initializePlot, previous plot provided, smart configurations can directly used plot functions. Consequently, scatter1 provide simple x y labels, scatter2 name labels metaData properties. scatter3 scatter4, use plotConfiguration defined smartConfig4 lead exact plot. left: scatter1; right: scatter2 left: scatter3; right: scatter4
code: time <- seq(0, 20, 0.1) myData <- data.frame(   x = time,   y = 2 * cos(time) ) myMetaData <- list(   x = list(     dimension = "Time",     unit = "min"   ),   y = list(     dimension = "Amplitude",     unit = "cm"   ) ) myMapping <- XYGDataMapping$new(   x = "x",   y = "y" )  smartConfig1 <- PlotConfiguration$new(data = myData) smartConfig2 <- PlotConfiguration$new(   data = myData,   dataMapping = myMapping ) smartConfig3 <- PlotConfiguration$new(   data = myData,   metaData = myMetaData ) smartConfig4 <- PlotConfiguration$new(   title = Label$new(text = "Cosinus", size = 14),   ylabel = "Variations",   data = myData,   metaData = myMetaData )  pSmart1 <- initializePlot(smartConfig1) pSmart2 <- initializePlot(smartConfig2) pSmart3 <- initializePlot(smartConfig3) pSmart4 <- initializePlot(smartConfig4) scatter1 <- addScatter(data = myData) scatter2 <- addScatter(   data = myData,   metaData = myMetaData )  scatter3 <- addScatter(   data = myData,   plotConfiguration = smartConfig4 ) scatter4 <- initializePlot(smartConfig4) scatter4 <- addScatter(   data = myData,   plotObject = scatter4 )

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: Background configuration defines configuration following Background elements: - plot - panel - xGrid - yGrid - xAxis - yAxis - legendPosition - watermark Except watermark legendPosition, text watermark position legend defined element LegendPositions enum, background fields LineElement BackgroundElement objects, define properties background element. PlotConfiguration inputs, default values defined current Theme, however default can overwritten. instance:

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: effect background configuration plots also quite straightforward: left: pBack1; right: pBack2
code: plotConfigurationBackground1 <- PlotConfiguration$new(watermark = "My Watermark")  pBack1 <- initializePlot(plotConfigurationBackground1)  plotConfigurationBackground1$background$watermark <- Label$new(text = "Hello world", color = "goldenrod4", size = 8) plotConfigurationBackground1$background$plot <- BackgroundElement$new(fill = "lemonchiffon", color = "goldenrod3", linetype = "solid") plotConfigurationBackground1$background$panel <- BackgroundElement$new(fill = "grey", color = "black", linetype = "solid") pBack2 <- initializePlot(plotConfigurationBackground1)

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: creating plot, possible change background configuration using following tlf methods: setBackground, setBackgroundPanelArea, setBackgroundPlotArea setGrid, setXGrid setYGrid setWatermark

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: methods setBackground, setBackgroundPanelArea, setBackgroundPlotArea require plot object properties update. Using previous example, scatter1,
code: setBackground(scatter1, fill = "lemonchiffon", color = "darkgreen", linetype = "solid") setBackgroundPanelArea(scatter1, fill = "lemonchiffon", color = "darkgreen", linetype = "solid")

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: methods setGrid, setXGrid, setYGrid similar require plot object grid properties updated. Using previous example scatter1:
code: setGrid(scatter1, linetype = "blank") setXGrid(scatter1, linetype = "blank") setYGrid(scatter1, linetype = "blank")

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: setWatermark method requires plot object, watermark, properties update. Among properties, following important ones: property alpha value 0 1 managing transparency watermark. closer 0, transparent watermark . closer 1, opaque watermark . property angle, angle watermark degrees. Using previous example scatter1:
code: setWatermark(scatter1, watermark = "Hello watermark !!") setWatermark(scatter1, watermark = "Confidential", angle = 45, size = 6, color = "firebrick")

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: fields xAxis yAxis PlotConfiguration object XAxisConfiguration YAxisConfiguration R6 class objects. define following plot properties: scale limits ticks ticklabels font property scale character string corresponding axis scale. Available scales “lin”, “log”, “discrete”, “reverse”, “sqrt”, “time”, “date” can accessed using enum Scaling. property limits vector defining range axis. Regarding ticks ticklabels, values directly passed managed ggplot2. value “default” leave management limits R. properties ticks ticklabels vectors defining plot ticks labels. vectors required length. value “default” leave management limits R. initializing XAxisConfiguration, YAxisConfiguration, PlotConfiguration objects, axis properties can passed .
code: myAxisConfiguration <- XAxisConfiguration$new()  myAxisConfiguration$scale #> [1] "identity" myAxisConfiguration$ticklabels #> list() #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "waiver"

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: methods setXAxis setYAxis require plot object, axis properties update. Using previous example, scatter1:
code: setXAxis(scatter1, limits = c(0.5, 20), scale = Scaling$sqrt) setXAxis(scatter1,   limits = c(0, 6 * pi),   ticks = seq(0, 6 * pi, pi),   ticklabels = c("0", "pi", paste0(seq(2, 6), "*pi")),   font = Font$new(color = "dodgerblue") )

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: field legend PlotConfiguration object LegendConfiguration R6 class object. defines following plot properties: title position caption property title character string corresponding legend title. property position character string corresponding legend position. Available legend positions “none”, “insideTop”, “insideTopLeft”, “insideLeft”, “insideBottomLeft”, “insideBottom”, “insideBottomRight”, “insideRight”, “insideTopRight”, “outsideTop”, “outsideTopLeft”, “outsideLeft”, “outsideBottomLeft”, “outsideBottom”, “outsideBottomRight”, “outsideRight”, “outsideTopRight” can accessed using enum LegendPositions. property caption data.frame defining caption properties legend.

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: Legend position can modified using function setLegendPosition methods setLegendPosition requires plot object, position defined elements enum LegendPositions Using previous example, scatter1:

title: Introduction to PlotConfiguration objects
text: class Theme allows user-friendly way set many default plot settings. allow smooth way set update themes, themes snapshots can saved json files using function saveThemeToJson(theme) can loaded json files using function loadThemeFromJson(jsonFile). order define theme current default, function useTheme(theme) needs called. shiny app created tune Theme objects live save json files. app, becomes quite easy create one’s theme clicks. call shiny app, users needed run function runThemeMaker().

title: plot-maker
text: plot properties can updated using navigation bars Labels, Background, Axes, Legend, Theme Aesthetics. examples illustrate briefly update properties. Labels navigation bar, font properties content common labels available. font properties ticks legend available properties Axes Legend. example highlights updates properties watermark indicates “watermark” instead “template” written bigger “goldenrod” color.  Background navigation bar includes properties fill, colors, sizes linetypes background elements. example highlights updates properties plot area (area around panel) filled “aliceblue” color uses “solid” “black” border.  Axes navigation bar includes properties axes lines (colors, sizes linetypes), font properties ticks well scales limits. example highlights updates Y-axis scale new limits defined ymin=0.1 ymax=10. Note limits taken account ymin ymax values used.  Legend navigation bar includes properties position legend (figure ). Fonts background yet accounted current version runPlotMaker().  Aesthetics navigation bar defines points, lines, ribbons errorbars plotted. indicated help text, using one predefined selection keys (next, , first, reset) use values available theme aesthetic map. value used define points, lines, ribbons errorbars plotted. example highlights updates lines plotted PK Ratio plot. Lines now “#000000” (black) color using concept theme linetype (theme map linetype solid, longdash, dotted line…).

title: theme-maker
text: Use function runThemeMaker() start theme-maker User Interface. function load shiny required UI set current theme defined UI.

title: theme-maker
text: upper left side UI, navigation bar indicates main properties can updated theme: Labels, Background, Axes, Legend, Aesthetic Maps Plot Configurations. Labels navigation bar (already available starting UI), font properties common labels available. font properties ticks legend available properties Axes Legend. Note Color properties use predefined list available colors illustrated figure , however, users can type add colors (e.g. hex colors).  Properties watermark available Labels navigation bar, include field Content allows define content watermark (example content template). Background navigation bar includes properties colors, sizes, linetypes background elements (illustrated ).  Axes navigation bar includes properties axes lines (colors, sizes linetypes) well font properties ticks (illustrated ).  Legend navigation bar includes properties position, fonts, background legend (illustrated ). title: Introduction to tlf-based workflow
text: aim vignette document illustrate typical workflow needed production plots using tlf-library.

title: Introduction to tlf-based workflow
text: main purpose tlf-library standardize production ggplot objects data produced OSPSuiteR package. , tlf-library requires ggplot2 package installed.

title: Introduction to tlf-based workflow
text: suggested workflow producing kind plot tlf-library illustrated figure .  standard workflow proceeds follows: Step 0 - Data gathering. Gather data tidy data.frame format. Step 1 - Data pre-processing Pre-process data using AggregationSummary class. Step 2 - Data grouping Use GroupMapping class specify groupings according data captioned figure legends. Step 3 - Data mapping. Use DataMapping class select independent dependent variables processed data well aesthetics used differentiate groupings data specified step 2. Step 4 - Plot configuration Set PlotConfiguration object define settings plot axis labeling, font sizes, watermarks. Step 5 - Plot generation Create ggplot object classes using dedicated plotting function. Steps 1, 2, 3, 4 mandatory. skipped, tlf-library uses default settings lieu objects created otherwise. Additionally, PlotConfiguration object DataMapping object can created independently. Sections 2 4 focus AggregationSummary, DataMapping, PlotConfiguration.

title: Introduction to tlf-based workflow

title: Introduction to tlf-based workflow
text: workflow assumes data plotted gathered form tidy dataframe. tidy format dataframe, measurement, simulation result experimental observation, described entirely one row. columns data.frame limited independent variable columns measurement (example, time IndividualId) dependent variable columns (case Organism|VenousBlood|Volume), hold value measurement. Since additional columns allowed, two dependent variables differing sets independent variables tidy dataframes. sequel, use dataset derived OSPSuiteR package: testData. Let’s look rows get sense data:

title: Introduction to tlf-based workflow
text: metaData variable associated data can used define additional information dimension unit column data.frame. lower limit quantification IndividualId profile can also stored metaData. format metaData currently expected list variable lists showing unit dimension.

title: Introduction to tlf-based workflow
text: common processing data aggregation. aggregation consists splitting data subsets, computing summary statistics , returning result convenient form. Visual predictive checks typical plots method useful. AggregationSummary class helper class simplifies use aggregation methods data. R6 class AggregationSummary automates computation multiple summary statistics raw data produced Step 0. output optional data pre-processing step dataframe column summary statistic. dataframe can input subsequent steps workflow. user also option generating metaData summary statistics evaluated. illustrate functions class example dataframe testData, let’s suppose individual IndividualId column, minimum mean value simulated Organism|VenousBlood|Volume column computed gender Gender column. AggregationSummary class works 3 steps: Three sets columns selected input dataframe data: independent variable set called xColumnNames (case, IndividualId column testData), grouping variables set called groupingColumnNames (Gender column testData) dependent variables set called yColumnNames (Organism|VenousBlood|Volume column testData). value independent variable xColumnNames, rows dataframe aggregated groups defined unique combinations elements grouping variable columns groupingColumnNames. Summary statistics (case, minimum mean) yColumnNames variables group evaluated. functions computing summary statistics specified initializing AggregationSummary, via aggregationFunctionsVector. User-specified descriptive names functions supplied via vector strings named aggregationFunctionNames. units dimensions outputs functions supplied via vectors strings named aggregationUnitsVector aggregationDimensionsVector, respectively. example, AggregationSummary object aggSummary instantiated follows: dataframe holds summary statistics aggregated rows stored dfHelper property resulting aggSummary object. Since two functions (min mean) specified aggregationFunctionsVector, dataframe aggSummary$dfHelper , addition xColumnNamesand groupingColumnNames columns, two additional columns named Simulated Min Simulated Mean, names specified aggregationFunctionNames. metaData corresponding columns resulting dataframes lists stored together list metaData xColumnNamesand groupingColumnNames columns. metaData new aggSummary$dfHelper dataframe stored metaDataHelper property aggSummary object. example, two metaData lists corresponding Simulated Min Simulated Mean columns also labeled Simulated Min Simulated Mean. contents list aggSummary$metaDataHelper :
code: aggSummary <- AggregationSummary$new(   data = testData,   metaData = testMetaData,   xColumnNames = "IndividualId",   groupingColumnNames = "Gender",   yColumnNames = "Organism|VenousBlood|Volume",   aggregationFunctionsVector = c(min, mean),   aggregationFunctionNames = c(     "Simulated Min",     "Simulated Mean"   ),   aggregationUnitsVector = c("l", "l"),   aggregationDimensionsVector = c(     "Volume",     "Volume"   ) ) head(aggSummary$dfHelper) # Currently issue with metaData of Gender aggSummary$metaDataHelper[[2]] <- NULL aggMetaData <- data.frame(   "unit" = sapply(aggSummary$metaDataHelper, function(x) {     x$unit   }),   "dimension" = sapply(aggSummary$metaDataHelper, function(x) {     x$dimension   }) )  knitr::kable(aggMetaData)

what: 3. Mapping and grouping of data: DataMapping class
title: Introduction to tlf-based workflow
text: role DataMapping class provide user-friendly interface indicate data plotted. cases, class needs initialized map variables x y, IndividualIds variable(s) group data. Thus, common input x y; however, advanced plots, input groupMapping may used often. advanced plots, subclasses derived DataMapping, use unique input default related advanced plot make easier use .

title: Introduction to tlf-based workflow
text: R6 class called Grouping can used group data subsets , final plots, distinguished aesthetically legend captions. addition, subsets can listed descriptive legend titles. example, Grouping object called grouping1 can used specify data tidy data.frame grouped “Compound” “Dose”: minimal input, legend associated grouping default title “Compound-Dose”. hand, custom title grouping legend can supplied user optional label input: two examples, default captions constructed hyphenating compound type dose amount row. Alternatively, captions can customized user supplying dataframe custom captions group input Grouping object constructor. format dataframe rightmost column contains desired captions, name rightmost column default legend title grouping, remaining columns define combinations row entries receive caption rightmost column. illustrate method, following dataframe mappingDataFrame used assign captions based entries “Dose” “Compound” columns. example, caption “6mg Aspirin” assigned row “Dose” entry 6 “Compound” entry “Aspirin”. default title legend results grouping name rightmost column, “Compound & Dose”. Note check.names option set FALSE creating dataframe mappingDataFrame, since legend title contains spaces instance. legend title can overridden another string using label input object constructor, case grouping2 . three Grouping objects, grouping1, grouping2, grouping3 respectively yield last three columns following dataframe: dataframe can also used create Grouping object subsets data based whether numeric grouping variable satisfies specific inequality. example, individuals testData can grouped according whether age exceeds 6 years first defining following dataframe: creating new grouping: new Grouping object grouping4 yields following captions
code: # Grouping by variable names: grouping1 <- Grouping$new(c("Compound", "Dose")) # Grouping by variable names and overwriting the default label: grouping2 <- Grouping$new(group = c("Compound", "Dose"), label = "Compound & Dose") # Grouping using a data.frame: mappingDataFrame <- data.frame(   Compound = c("Aspirin", "Aspirin", "Sugar", "Sugar"),   Dose = c(6, 3, 6, 3),   "Compound & Dose" = c(     "6mg of Aspirin",     "3mg of Aspirin",     "6mg of Sugar",     "3mg of Sugar"   ),   check.names = FALSE ) knitr::kable(mappingDataFrame) grouping3 <- Grouping$new(group = mappingDataFrame) # Apply the mapping to get the grouping captions: groupingsDataFrame <- data.frame(   testData$IndividualId,   testData$Dose,   testData$Compound,   grouping1$getCaptions(testData),   grouping2$getCaptions(testData),   grouping3$getCaptions(testData) )  names(groupingsDataFrame) <- c(   "IndividualId", "Dose", "Compound",   grouping1$label, grouping2$label, grouping3$label )  # Show results for all groupings: knitr::kable(groupingsDataFrame) # Grouping using a data.frame: binningDataFrame <- data.frame(   Age = I(list(c(0, 6), c(7, 100))),   "Age Range" = c(     "Age 6 or lower",     "Above age 6"   ),   check.names = FALSE ) grouping4 <- Grouping$new(group = binningDataFrame) # Apply the mapping to get the grouping captions: testData$Age <- testData$`Organism|Age` binnedGroupingsDataFrame <- data.frame(   testData$IndividualId,   testData$Age,   grouping4$getCaptions(testData) )  names(binnedGroupingsDataFrame) <- c("IndividualId", "Age", grouping4$label)  # Show results for all groupings: knitr::kable(binnedGroupingsDataFrame)

title: Introduction to tlf-based workflow
text: additional R6 class called GroupMapping maps Grouping objects aesthetic parameters color linetype. distinguish “Compound” “Dose” groups color use captions legend title specified grouping2, following groupings object groups1 constructed: GroupMapping object groups2 can also constructed quickly directly associating aesthetic, color, vector dataframe column names: Grouping object directly:
code: # Map groups to aesthtic properties groups1 <- GroupMapping$new(color = grouping2) # Map groups to aesthtic properties groups2 <- GroupMapping$new(color = c("Compound", "Dose")) # Map groups to aesthetic properties groups3 <- GroupMapping$new(color = Grouping$new(   group = c("Compound", "Dose"),   label = c("Compound & Dose") ))

title: tlf 1.1.0
text: tlf library R package compatible ospsuite package. tlf provides environment create standardized plots tables output extracted ospsuite. following release notes aim presenting features tlf library alpha release report feedback.

title: tlf 1.1.0
text: PK Ratio Plots: Users can plot PK Ratios associated predefined ratio limits function plotPKRatio. can also get measure many ratios predefined ratio limits function getPKRatioMeasure. Users can plot time profiles function plotTimeProfile. Histograms: Users can plot histograms function plotHistogram. Box Whiskers: Users can plot box whiskers function plotBoxWhisker. Plot Configuration: Users can create use standardized plots setting configuration using Theme PlotConfiguration. configurations allows easy definitions labels, background axes properties.
